articles.headline: Evangelicals See Donald Trump as Man of Conviction, if Not Faith
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump might seem an odd fit among those who prize traditional religious values, yet polls increasingly show him leading the crowded Republican field among evangelical voters.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump might seem an odd fit among those who prize traditional religious values, yet polls increasingly show him leading the crowded Republican field among evangelical voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buford Arning, a retired building supply executive in Statesville, N.C., went to church each week until a pinched nerve made it hard for him to leave his house. He believes in living a faith-filled life. But he does not demand piety of his preferred presidential candidate, Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: In Davos, Shunning Controversy in Favor of Restrained Debate
articles.snippet: The World Economic Forum has often been a stage for meaningful debate on global issues. But a decision to revoke North Korea's invitation shows how sanitized the forum has become.
articles.abstract: The World Economic Forum has often been a stage for meaningful debate on global issues. But a decision to revoke North Korea's invitation shows how sanitized the forum has become.
articles.lead_paragraph: The invitation was sent. And then, two weeks later, revoked.

articles.headline: Seeking Ranchland in Texas, Where Wealth Is Measured in Acres
articles.snippet: As the price of oil has declined, one investor is betting that the price of land will, too. So he is raising a $100 million private equity fund to buy Texas ranches.
articles.abstract: As the price of oil has declined, one investor is betting that the price of land will, too. So he is raising a $100 million private equity fund to buy Texas ranches.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jay Ellis, an investment fund founder, may be the only person in Texas who is giddy about collapsing oil prices.

articles.headline: As More Pay by Smartphone, Banks Scramble to Keep Up
articles.snippet: A millennial-led shift to digital financial services could upend the consumer banking industry.
articles.abstract: A millennial-led shift to digital financial services could upend the consumer banking industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ryan Craine hates carrying cash and finds writing checks to be a headache. He doesn’t do much of either anymore — he mostly uses his smartphone to pay for things.

articles.headline: U.S.-Iranian Swaps Pit Compassion Against Costs
articles.snippet: While critics argue that trading prisoners encourages others to target Americans, President Obama has deemed certain releases a reasonable trade-off.
articles.abstract: While critics argue that trading prisoners encourages others to target Americans, President Obama has deemed certain releases a reasonable trade-off.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama flew to Boise, Idaho, for a speech last winter, he met privately with the wife of an Iranian-American pastor held prisoner in Iran since 2012. Freeing her husband, he promised, was one of his top priorities.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Set for a Long Slog Against Bernie Sanders
articles.snippet: Facing a tougher-than-expected challenge from Mr. Sanders, Mrs. Clinton’s campaign is preparing for a primary fight that could stretch into late April or early May.
articles.abstract: Facing a tougher-than-expected challenge from Mr. Sanders, Mrs. Clinton’s campaign is preparing for a primary fight that could stretch into late April or early May.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing a tougher than expected challenge from Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, Hillary Clinton’s campaign is preparing for a primary fight that could stretch into late April or early May and require a sprawling field operation in states and territories from Pennsylvania to Guam.

articles.headline: China G.D.P. Growth at Slowest Pace Since 2009, Data Shows
articles.snippet: The economy grew at a 6.8 percent pace in the fourth quarter, official data released Tuesday showed — the slowest expansion since March 2009.
articles.abstract: The economy grew at a 6.8 percent pace in the fourth quarter, official data released Tuesday showed — the slowest expansion since March 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s growth slowed further last year, adding to the troubling economic picture that is unsettling investors around the world.

articles.headline: Week of Attacks, Scores of Civilian Deaths and a Question: Why Them?
articles.snippet: The seemingly random killings last week in Burkina Faso, Indonesia, Iraq and Turkey highlighted the strategy of militants determined to sow fear in disparate corners of the world.
articles.abstract: The seemingly random killings last week in Burkina Faso, Indonesia, Iraq and Turkey highlighted the strategy of militants determined to sow fear in disparate corners of the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: A family of Canadian volunteers dedicated to alleviating poverty in Africa. A group of intrepid German retirees on a tour of Turkey and the Middle East. An Iraqi who had gone to Baghdad seeking refuge from the jihadist violence of his hometown. A Canadian audiologist who had fallen in love with Indonesia.

articles.headline: China’s Fading Factories Weigh on an Already Slowing Economy
articles.snippet: The economic slump has created a tricky situation for Beijing, as it tries to shepherd the economy through a transition.
articles.abstract: The economic slump has created a tricky situation for Beijing, as it tries to shepherd the economy through a transition.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONGGUAN, China — Walking around an abandoned furniture factory, Fang Minghua pointed out the workshops where several hundred employees once toiled, transforming sheets of raw wood into TV stands or wardrobes for the aspiring middle class in China and other emerging economies.

articles.headline: Microsoft Acquires Minecraft App for Schools
articles.snippet: Microsoft hopes the classroom version of the popular video game will help it achieve broader company objectives in education.
articles.abstract: Microsoft hopes the classroom version of the popular video game will help it achieve broader company objectives in education.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Microsoft acquired the creator of the game Minecraft in 2014, the giant software company instantly got a cachet bump with children, picking up a blockbuster game app for a generation that didn’t depend on its products the way their parents did.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Obama Immigration Actions
articles.snippet: A coalition of 26 states has sued over the president’s efforts to provide work permits for millions of illegal immigrants, accusing him of abuse of power.
articles.abstract: A coalition of 26 states has sued over the president’s efforts to provide work permits for millions of illegal immigrants, accusing him of abuse of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said Tuesday that it would consider a legal challenge to President Obama’s overhaul of the nation’s immigration rules, agreeing to examine the reach of presidential power as it decides the fate of one of his most far-reaching executive actions.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Michael D. Shear
